Graphical abstract The energetic ammonium salts represent a class of oxidizer materials that are extensively utilized in contemporary propellant systems. However, the catalytic pyrolysis mechanisms of these salts remain inadequately explored, hindering the efficient application of new energetic ammonium salts. In this study, taking typical energetic ammonium salts (ammonium perchlorate (AP), ammonium nitrate (AN) and ammonium dinitramide (ADN)) as examples, their pyrolysis on the surface of the prepared Fe single-atom catalysts and the combustion flames of the powders were investigated. We learned that Fe single-atoms can promote the pyrolysis and enhance the flame intensity of ammonium salts. The mechanism of Fe single-atom catalyzed ammonium salts has been investigated through density-functional-theory (DFT) calculations, and the results well explained the experimental phenomena. The AP molecule produces oxygen most readily, primarily through the pyrolysis of *ClO4 (−3.70 eV). The idea of solving the heat-absorbing decomposition of AN is proposed to catalyze its complete decomposition and to avoid the production of NO. The low decomposition temperature of ADN is due to the five major pyrolysis pathways of the molecule and the presence of self-catalytic intermediates. This paper offers guidelines for comprehending the pyrolysis and combustion mechanisms of energetic ammonium salts. Keywords Energetic ammonium salts Single-atom catalysts Combustion Pyrolysis mechanisms DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The energetic ammonium salts are a class of oxidizer materials widely employed in modern solid propellant systems, among which the most representative examples include ammonium perchlorate (AP), ammonium nitrate (AN) and ammonium dinitramide (ADN) [1]. At present, AP is the most widely used oxidizer component in solid propellants due to its high oxygen content, high energy release, and high gas generation during decomposition. However, since AP molecules contain chlorine (Cl) elements, their combustion releases significant amounts of toxic and harmful products, posing serious risks to the environment and human health [2,3]. In response to the increasingly serious environmental pollution problem, a variety of green oxidizers have been developed to replace the role of AP in solid propellants [4,5]. The most popular ones are AN and ADN, which have higher nitrogen content. These two molecules are composed of only nitrogen (N), hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O), and the combustion products of the molecules are less polluting to the environment [6]. Yet, there are still a number of problems that affect the wide-scale application of AN and ADN. For instance, the issue of pyrolytic heat absorption by AN affects the energy release of the propellant [7], while the strong hygroscopic behavior of ADN molecules impacts its storage and usage [8]. At its core, the primary challenge stems from an incomplete understanding of the molecular characteristics of these ammonium salts. To fully harness energetic ammonium salts, systematic elucidation of their thermal decomposition mechanisms is imperative, particularly focusing on bond cleavage pathways and intermediate evolution. The positive oxygen balance values of AP (+34.05 %), AN (+19.99 %), and ADN (+25.79 %) indicate that their pyrolysis can provide oxygen to the propellant system, which promotes oxidative reactions and enhances combustion [9,10]. Since NH4 + is a universal component of ammonium salts, the differences in their properties are primarily attributed to the anionic part. These three compounds exhibit significantly distinct pyrolysis behaviors, resulting in variations in energy release and gas generation within the propellant. The current systematic study of the pyrolysis mechanisms of such ammonium salt oxidizers remains insufficient, particularly in the domain of molecular pyrolysis based on first-principles calculations. This significantly impedes the development of novel high-performance ammonium salt oxidizers. To expand the practical utilization of these energetic materials, it is imperative to conduct comprehensive investigations and elucidate their detailed pyrolysis mechanisms. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are a unique class of catalysts known for their high efficiency, selectivity, and superior catalytic performance compared to traditional catalysts [11–13]. Currently, SACs are widely used in various energy conversion catalytic reactions, including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [14,15]. With the development of advanced characterization techniques and synthesis strategies, such as defect engineering, spatially constrained methods, and coordinated design approaches [16,17], SACs have been successfully synthesized on a variety of substrates (e.g., metal oxides, graphene, and metal carbides) [18,19]. The transition metal single atoms are highly dispersed, enhancing the catalytic activity [20]. Owing to their isolated active sites, the catalytic mechanisms of SACs can be precisely elucidated, making them highly advantageous for studying the thermal decomposition of energetic ammonium salts. In this paper, a series of catalysts (FeN@C-x) loaded with Fe single-atoms in graphite lattice were first prepared using wet ball milling method [21,22]. The optimal ball milling scheme was obtained by studying the catalytic effect of the catalysts on AP. The pyrolysis products of AP, AN and ADN were further investigated and the catalytic pyrolysis mechanisms were summarized in depth in conjunction with density functional theory (DFT) calculations [23–26]. The similarities and differences in the catalytic pyrolysis mechanisms of AP, AN, and ADN were systematically analyzed by categorizing the energetic ammonium salts into acidic (characteristic groups) and basic (common groups) components. In addition, the reaction pathways for the catalytic pyrolysis of ammonium salts, including the formation and transformation mechanisms of key intermediates, were elucidated. The Gibbs free energies of these pyrolysis reactions were determined. Furthermore, the adsorption and desorption behaviors of various gas products on the catalyst surface, as well as electron transfer phenomena, were systematically studied. Our study provides a theoretical explanation for the segmental pyrolysis of AP, the heat absorption decomposition of AN, and the differences in energy release during the pyrolysis of AP, AN, and ADN. This study enhances our understanding of the pyrolysis behavior of energetic ammonium salts and provides a theoretical basis for their efficient utilization in propellant systems or energy storage. 2 Methods and materials 2.1 Raw materials Graphite flake (G, 99.95 %, metal basis, 3000 mesh) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Co., Ltd. (China), Iron(II) phthalocyanine (FePc, 98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. (China), AP was purchased from Dalian North Potassium Chlorate Co., Ltd. (China), AN was purchased from Shanxi Northern Xingan Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. (China), ADN was purchased from Xi’an Modern Chemistry Research Institute (China). They were commercial materials of analytical grade and were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of Gm Raw material G has thicker layers with more curling and bending areas. Ball milled graphite (Gm) produces a thinner thickness and flatter surface. Gm was prepared using the wet milling method. In a typical experiment, 2.0 g of G and an appropriate quantity of zirconium beads (1 ± 0.2 mm in diameter, filling 2/3 of the jar volume) were placed in a 100 ml agate ball mill jar. The solvent (deionized water: anhydrous ethanol = 5:1) was added dropwise until the material was just submerged. The ball milling process was conducted at 450 rpm for 20 h. The ball-milled material was collected by centrifugation (11,000 r/min, 5 min, 20 °C). Subsequently, the material was ultrasonically dispersed in a solution (deionized water: anhydrous ethanol = 9:1), snap-frozen using liquid nitrogen, and then subjected to vacuum freeze-drying at −50 °C for 3 days to yield the fluffy product. 2.3 Synthesis of FeN@C-7 single-atom catalysts The obtained Gm (0.575 g) was subjected to ball milling with FePc (1.425 g). The details of the ball milling procedure were consistent with those used in the synthesis of Gm. A total weight of 2.0 g of material and an appropriate amount of zirconium beads (1 ± 0.2 mm in diameter, filling 2/3 of the jar volume) were placed in a 100 ml agate ball mill jar. The solvent (deionized water: anhydrous ethanol = 5:1) was added dropwise until the material was just submerged. The ball milling process was conducted at 450 rpm for 20 h. The ball-milled material was collected by centrifugation and washed by centrifugation with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water alternately for three times (11000 r/min, 5 min, 20 °C). The purified material was then ultrasonically dispersed in a solution (deionized water: anhydrous ethanol = 9:1), snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen, and vacuum freeze-dried at −50 °C for 3 days to obtain the fluffy product. The iron content in FePc is 9.8255 %, and the calculated iron content in the mixture is 7 %, so the catalyst is denoted as FeN@C-7. Similarly, the same preparation process was used to produce catalysts with varying iron contents, designated as FeN@C-1, FeN@C-3, FeN@C-5, FeN@C-7.5, FeN@C-8, FeN@C-8.5, FeN@C-9, and FeN@C-9.5. 2.4 Morphological characterization The samples were characterized by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi Regulus SU8100) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM F200). The catalyst surface was characterized using a double spherical aberration corrected transmission electron microscope (STEM, Spectra 300 (S)TEM) to observe Fe single atoms. The elemental composition of the sample was analyzed using the energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, JED-2300 T). The particle size analysis was performed with the Malvern ZS90 nanoparticle sizer. The X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) and the infrared spectrometer (IR, Bruker Invenio S) were used to study the crystal structure of the samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) was to investigate the surface state using a monochromatic Al source (1486.6 eV). X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analyses were performed by the TableXAFS-500A. The Fe content of the sample was determined using the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent 720ES). 2.5 Thermal characterization Thermal decomposition characteristics of AP, AN and ADN were determined by thermogravimetric-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC, TGA/DSC 3+, Mettler Toledo). Specifically, the AP, AN and ADN samples (1.0–1.2 mg) were placed in an alumina crucible (with a lid that has a small hole) and heated at a constant rate of 10 °C·min−1 from 30 to 500 °C, 400 °C and 300 °C, respectively. The tests were performed under N2 atmosphere at a flow rate of 50 ml·min−1. In addition, the pyrolysis products were analyzed using a Simultaneous Thermal Analysis-Mass Spectrometry-Infrared Coupler (TG-DSC-MS-IR, Netzsch STA449 + QMS403). Argon (Ar, 50 ml·min−1) was utilized as the carrier gas to eliminate the influence of N2 on the detection of gaseous products. The mass-to-charge ratio range of the MS was 2–200, and the IR spectra were recorded in the range of 500–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The heating rate of the samples (AP samples for 1.6–1.8 mg, AN and ADN samples for 1.4–1.5 mg) was consistent with the TG-DSC analysis, which was 10 °C·min−1. The tested temperature ranges were from 30 to 520 °C for AP samples, and from 30 to 400 °C for AN and ADN samples, respectively. The amount of catalyst used was consistently 5 wt%. In addition, the burning flame of these samples were tested. Powder samples (20 mg) were placed in a concave mold and the samples were ignited using a nickel-chromium alloy wire connected to a direct current power supply (GWINSTEK GPS-18500). The entire ignition process was filmed by a high-speed camera. To promote powder combustion, the samples were supplemented with ultrafine aluminum powder (Al, 1 µm), where the ratio of Al powder to oxidant was 1:3.5. 2.6 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The DFT calculations [27–29] were performed using the Materials Studio software. The Generalized-Gradient-Approximation method, in the form of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof approximation (GGA-PBE) [30–32], was used to calculate the exchange correlation energy. The spin unrestricted method was used to model spin polarization. The Monkhorst-Pack scheme (4 × 4 × 1) was used for sampling the Brillouin zone [33–35]. Orbital cutoff quality was 4.6 Å. The SCF tolerance was 1.0 × 10−7 Ha per atom. The optimization ends when the energy, maximum force and maximum displacement were smaller than 1.0 × 10−7 Ha per atom, 0.001 Ha·Å−1 and 0.001 Å, respectively. A 15 Å vacuum layer was set up to eliminate interlayer interactions [36,37]. Reaction free energy change ( Δ G ) was calculated according to this: (R0) Δ G = Δ E DFT + Δ E ZPE - T Δ S where Δ E DFT and Δ E ZPE are the calculated total energy difference and zero-point energy difference, T Δ S is the entropy contribution at 298.15 K [38,39]. And the entropies of adsorbate and adsorption site are negligible. 2.7 Catalytic pyrolysis reaction mechanism The ammonium salts all contain the NH4 + ion, and their initial pyrolysis steps follow similar mechanisms. During pyrolysis, NH4 + readily undergoes the transfer of a hydrogen atom, resulting in the formation of thermodynamically stable ammonia gas and the corresponding acidic species. Therefore, the initial stages of the pyrolysis reactions for AP, AN, and ADN can be described as follows: (R1) NH 4 ClO 4 → NH 3 + HClO 4 (R2) NH 4 NO 3 → NH 3 + HNO 3 (R3) NH 4 N NO 2 2 → NH 3 + HN NO 2 2 During the thermal decomposition of ammonium salts, numerous NH3 molecules and acidic species interact on the catalyst surface, where the active sites are critical for the pyrolysis of these molecules. To elucidate the pyrolysis mechanisms of AP, AN, and ADN, we investigated the reaction mechanisms of NH3, HClO4, HNO3, and HN(NO2)2 on the catalyst surface, respectively. To facilitate the analysis of the reaction mechanism, the NHE potential was introduced. The NHE potential is defined for the following half-reaction [39]: (R4) H 2 ( g ) ↔ H sol + + e M where the NHE potential is considered to be zero: (R5) E H + + E e - = 0.5 E H 2 The catalytic pyrolysis of the NH3 molecule is examined as an integral component of the pyrolysis process for all ammonium salts. With the process of a single electron transfer, the adsorption and the main oxidation reactions of NH3 at the active sites (*) on the catalyst surface are as follows: (R6) * + NH 3 → ∗ NH 3 (R7) *NH 3 → ∗ NH 2 + 0.5 H 2 (R8) *NH 2 → ∗ NH + 0.5 H 2 (R9) *NH → ∗ N + 0.5 H 2 (R10) *N + H 2 O → ∗ NOH + 0.5 H 2 (R11) *NOH → ∗ NO + 0.5 H 2 Since the pyrolysis (reduction) of NH3 produces H atoms (0.5 H2), it follows that these H atoms are consumed in oxidation processes (e.g., HClO4 pyrolysis) according to the principle of mass conservation. Consequently, we propose the reaction mechanisms for the pyrolysis of these characteristic gases. The catalytic pyrolysis of HClO4 was studied separately as a characteristic part of AP pyrolysis. The adsorption and the main reduction reactions of HClO4 on the catalyst surface are as follows: (R12) ∗ + HClO 4 → *HClO 4 (R13) *HClO 4 + 0.5 H 2 → *ClO 3 + H 2 O (R14) ∗ ClO 3 + 0.5 H 2 → *HClO 3 (R15) *HClO 3 + 0.5 H 2 → *ClO 2 + H 2 O (R16) ∗ ClO 2 + 0.5 H 2 → *HClO 2 (R17) *HClO 2 + 0.5 H 2 → *ClO + H 2 O (R18) ∗ ClO + 0.5 H 2 → *HClO (R19) *HClO + 0.5 H 2 → ∗ Cl + H 2 O (R20) *Cl + 0.5 H 2 → ∗ HCl The catalytic pyrolysis of HNO3 was investigated independently as a distinctive component of AN pyrolysis. The adsorption and the main reduction reactions of HNO3 on the catalyst surface are as follows: (R21) ∗ + HNO 3 → *HNO 3 (R22) ∗ HNO 3 + 0.5 H 2 → *NO 2 + H 2 O (R23) ∗ NO 2 + 0.5H 2 → *HNO 2 (R24) ∗ HNO 2 + 0.5 H 2 → *NO + H 2 O (R25) ∗ NO + 0.5H 2 → *NOH (R26) ∗ NOH + 0.5 H 2 → *N + H 2 O (R27) ∗ N + NO → *N 2 O (R28) ∗ N → 0.5* + 0.5*N 2 The catalytic pyrolysis of HN(NO2)2 was investigated separately as a characteristic feature of ADN pyrolysis. The adsorption and characteristic reduction reactions of HN(NO2)2 on the catalyst surface are as follows: (R29) ∗ + HN NO 2 2 → ∗ HN NO 2 2 (R30) ∗ HN NO 2 2 → ∗ HN NO 2 + NO 2 (R31) ∗ HN NO 2 2 → ∗ HN 2 O 3 I + NO (R32) ∗ HN NO 2 2 → ∗ HN 2 O 3 I I + NO (R33) ∗ HN NO 2 2 + 0.5 H 2 → ∗ N NO 2 NO + H 2 O (R34) ∗ HN NO 2 2 → ∗ N 2 O + HNO 3 (R35) ∗ HN 2 O 3 I + 0.5 H 2 → ∗ NO NO + H 2 O (R36) ∗ HN 2 O 3 I I → ∗ N NO 2 + H 2 O (R37) ∗ N NO 2 → ∗ N + NO 2 (R38) ∗ NO NO → ∗ NO + NO The pyrolysis of ADN yields HNO3 (R34), which constitutes the initial product in the pyrolysis of AN. Since AN and ADN pyrolysis produce some of the same intermediate products, which have been discussed in the pyrolysis of AN. The pyrolysis mechanism of ADN is examined with a focus on its distinctive components. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure of FeN@C-7 The microscopic morphologies of the prepared samples were characterized, and the flowchart of the experiment is given in Fig. 1 -a. Fig. 1-b is the SEM images of FeN@C-7, which shows a rougher surface compared to the raw material morphologies (Fig. S1-a, b, d, e). The main reason is that Fe, N atoms are embedded in the graphite lattice due to external force, which causes rearrangement of atoms on the surface. In addition, the difference in particle size between Gm and G was analyzed (Fig. S1-c and f), and it was found that the particle size of Gm increased after ball milling. This is due to the large number of curled and bent structures in G. The ball milling treatment flattens these structures, resulting in a flatter surface and increased particle size of Gm (average particle size changes from 4.554 µm to 7.991 µm). These flattened surface structures facilitate the loading of single-atoms. Fig. 1-c and Fig. S2 present the TEM images of FeN@C-7, revealing an ultrathin layered structure. Measurements indicate a crystalline spacing of 0.361 nm. Upon comparison with the standard PDF card for graphene (PDF#89-8487), it is evident that this crystal plane does not correspond to any of graphene's crystal planes. This discrepancy is attributed to the successful loading of single-atoms, which has altered the crystal spacing. Besides, the crystal diffraction rings of FeN@C-7 were tested (Fig. 1-d). By analyzing the size of the diffraction rings, the first three interplanar spacings were found to be 0.360 nm, 0.220 nm, and 0.131 nm, respectively. Compared with the main crystal planes of graphene (002) (2θ = 26.55°, d = 0.335 nm) and (101) (2θ = 44.57°, d = 0.203 nm), it was found that the overall interplanar spacing of the catalyst is significantly different from that of graphene. Due to the mechanical force of ball milling, the interplanar spacing of graphene underwent certain changes. Analyzed the elemental distribution on the FeN@C-7 surface (Fig. 1-e), which shows that the C element has the strongest signal, and the N, O and Fe elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of the catalyst. Combined with EDS analysis (Fig. S3), the elemental contents on the FeN@C-7 surface were obtained as C (80.88 %) > N (11.68 %) > Fe (3.75 %) > O (3.69 %) in descending order. Since EDS can only analyze surface elements, ICP-OES testing was conducted to further investigate the Fe content in the catalyst (Table S1). The average result of three ICP tests indicates that the actual Fe element content in the catalyst is 5.57 %. These are Fe atoms stably loaded onto the graphene lattice. To verify the bonding mode of Fe atoms in FeN@C-7 catalysts, we performed synchrotron radiation tests (Fig. 1-f and g). By analyzing the XANES spectra and FT-EXAFS spectra, it can be known that the Fe atoms are mainly bonded with N atoms and are stabilized together in the graphite lattice. The wavelet transform (WT) of x(k) gives an intuitive way of demonstrating the atomically state of the Fe atoms in the FeN@C-7 by comparison with the Fe foil reference. It is clear that the survival of Fe–N bonds is observed in the FeN@C-7 catalyst, which is distinctly different from the Fe–Fe bonds of Fe foil (Fig. 1-h and i) [40]. Furthermore, to validate the successful synthesis of Fe single atoms in the catalyst, we performed STEM characterization. Fig. 2 clearly reveals Fe single-atoms within the graphite lattice. IFFT (Inverse Fast Fourier Transform) analysis was applied to STEM images, revealing enhanced details of Fe single atoms (Fig. S4). Complementary STEM-EDS analysis (Fig. S5) detected distinct characteristic signals of Fe and N, confirming their atomic-scale homogeneous dispersion. The structures of the samples were investigated using XRD and IR (Fig. 3 -a and b). Analysis of the XRD patterns reveals that the FeN@C-7 catalyst after ball-milling exhibits distinct diffraction peaks compared to the physically mixed sample. Notably, ball milling induces modifications to the crystalline structure of graphene, generating a new diffraction peak at 15.72°. And the intensity of this peak was found to correlate with the amount of FePc, the raw material for ball milling. With the increase of FePc content in the ball milling raw materials, the intensity of the diffraction peak at 15.72° intensifies (Figs. S6 and S7). The IR data corroborate these findings, showing a change in the characteristic Fe peak intensity at 717.13 cm−1 after ball-milling. Additionally, Fig. S8 demonstrates that the increase in Fe content within the ball-milling raw material results in significant alterations in the infrared absorption peaks, consistent with the trends observed in the XRD patterns. In order to investigate the crystal structure of FeN@C-7, XPS analysis was conducted on the samples (Fig. 4 ). The ball-milled FeN@C-7 exhibited partial alterations in nitrogen loading and structure compared to the physically mixed catalyst. Specifically, the central nitrogen (FeN4) within the FePc molecule was embedded into the graphite lattice, while heterocyclic nitrogen (Aza N) was partially removed by washing and partly incorporated into the graphite lattice as graphitic nitrogen. Additionally, there was a significant increase in oxygen content within the graphite lattice post-ball milling. Comparison of Fe2p spectra before and after ball milling reveals a broader peak width for FeN@C-7. Given the coexistence of multiple Fe oxidation states within 709 ∼ 711 eV (Table S2), we attribute this broadening to ball milling-induced partial conversion of Fe (II) to Fe (III). Analysis of the graphite XPS data (Fig. S9) revealed that wet milling introduces more oxygen defects into the graphite lattice, which enhances the adsorption of ammonium salts on the catalyst surface. 3.2 Catalytic performance The pyrolysis performance of energetic ammonium salts was investigated by TG-DSC. Specifically, the catalytic pyrolysis of AP was explored using ball-milling catalysts with different Fe contents (Fig. S10). The results indicated that FeN@C-7 exhibited the highest catalytic activity among all tested catalysts, and thus was selected for subsequent catalytic studies. The TG-DSC curves of AP, AN and ADN catalyzed by FeN@C-7 were given in Fig. 5 . Under identical conditions, the thermal decomposition temperatures of these compounds exhibit significant variations: AP undergoes complete decomposition at 352.97 °C, AN at 268.34 °C, and ADN at 209.89 °C (Fig. 5-a–c). These differences are primarily due to the distinct pyrolysis mechanisms of their respective acidic components (HClO4 for AP, HNO3 for AN, and HN(NO2)2 for ADN). Since the pyrolysis rate of AP is slow, enhancing its pyrolysis rate can effectively improve the combustion performance. The pyrolysis of AP has two phases, low-temperature decomposition (LTD) and high-temperature decomposition (HTD). Strategies to reduce HTD are very effective in improving combustion performance. From Fig. 5-d, FeN@C-7 advanced the HTD peak by 61.17 °C of AP. In addition, graphite significantly slows down the pyrolysis rates of AN and ADN (Fig. 5-e and f). But when the graphite was loaded with 5.57 wt% Fe atoms (FeN@C-7) it showed a good catalytic efficiency on AN pyrolysis. The heat absorption of AN pyrolysis was significantly reduced (as can be found by comparing the crystal transformation peak area of AN). The catalysis of ADN by FeN@C-7 is a different case. Since the pyrolysis temperature of pure ADN is already low, the focus of catalyzing ADN is to enhance the exothermic efficiency of ADN per unit time. As shown in Fig. S11, FeN@C-7 was able to significantly promote the concentrated exotherm of ADN and advance the complete decomposition temperature of ADN from 226.59 °C to 209.89 °C (Fig. 5-c). To further investigate the catalytic pyrolysis products of AP, AN, and ADN, the quadruple function instrument (TG-DSC-MS-IR) was used under an argon (Ar) environment to analyze their pyrolysis products. Fig. S12 shows the TG-DSC curves of ammonium salt pyrolysis under the Ar environment. Compared to catalysis under N2 conditions, the catalytic effect on ADN became more pronounced. Fig. 6 gives the mass spectral analysis of the pyrolysis gas of the ammonium salts. The mass spectra of the gas products are mainly distributed at m/z = 16 (NH2), 17 (NH3), 18 (H2O), 28 (N2), 30 (NO), 32 (O2) and 44 (N2O/CO2). It can be found that FeN@C-7 has made the pyrolysis gases of AP more concentrated, which is conducive to the energy release of the propellant system. The gas signals of AN and ADN are significantly enhanced, which suggests that the FeN@C-7 catalyst can promote their complete decomposition and reduce the generation of intermediates, which is conducive to the efficient application of the system's energy. From the yield of N2 (m/z = 28) from all three, it can be seen that the gas concentration noticeably increases after adding FeN@C-7, as this gas is the final product of complete combustion. On the other hand, by comparison, ADN has the strongest ability to produce N2, while AP has the weakest, which conforms to the rule of nitrogen content in molecules. Combined with the 3D infrared spectra analysis of pyrolysis gases, a similar pattern can be found. FeN@C-7 can accelerate the thermal decomposition of AP, and a large concentration of gas signals is detected around 350 °C (Fig. 7 -a and b). AN and ADN were affected by the catalyst, and the gas products became more homogeneous. The presence of FeN@C-7 could reduce the occurrence of side reactions and improve the pyrolysis efficiency (Fig. 7-c–f). The main pyrolysis gas products of AP, AN and ADN can be determined from the wavenumbers of the IR spectra. These characteristic wavenumbers correspond to the following substances: H2O and NH3 (4000–3400 cm−1), HCl (3100–2600 cm−1), CO2 (2400–2300 cm−1), N2O (2300–2100 cm−1), NO, N2O and N2 (1850–1250 cm−1), ClO4 − (750–600 cm−1) and NO3 − (1000–800 cm−1). Since the IR detector is located at the end, it is normal for there to be a lag in gas temperature and for some gas signals to be weakened. Comparison of the IR characteristic spectra (Fig. 8 -a and b) revealed that the complete decomposition temperature of AP was advanced by the catalyst, and a large amount of N2O, NO, and N2 gases were produced at 349.78 °C. The IR signals of the gases of AN were significantly enhanced at 400.80 °C (Fig. 8-c and d), with only one major peak (1200–1850 cm−1), and other side reaction products (NO3 −) were obviously reduced, indicating that the pyrolysis gas production of AN was more concentrated. For ADN, FeN@C-7 led to a decrease in the pyrolysis temperature, with the most gas products being produced at 200.74 °C (Fig. 8-e and f). The combustion flame propagation process was recorded using a high-speed camera for these Al-containing samples (Fig. 9 ). The combustion process of all these samples ejected tiny bright particles, which is due to the fact that Al cannot be combusted completely. Among them, AN combustion ejected the most particles, which is due to the combustion performance of AN is the weakest among the three, consistent with the previous analysis. Comparing the combustion flames before and after the addition of FeN@C-7 catalyst, it can be seen that the combustion time is shortened and the overall flame intensity is increased. FeN@C-7 has the best combustion promotion effect on AP (bigger and brighter flame, more rapid decomposition), the promotion effect on AN is mainly in the more concentrated flame in the early stage (more complete pyrolysis and gas production), and the promotion effect on ADN is mainly shorten the burning time and slightly increase the flame intensity. Using the catalytic pyrolysis of AP as a benchmark, we compared representative nanoscale Fe-based catalysts and Fe-containing bimetallic catalysts. As shown in Table 1 , our synthesized single-atom Fe catalyst outperforms conventional metal oxides/bimetallic oxides and exhibits catalytic efficiency comparable to that of CuFe bimetallic MOF. Although nanosheet Prussian blue (Fe2+/Fe3+) shows slightly superior catalytic performance for AP pyrolysis, its complex preparation method offers no practical advantage in propellant applications. It is noteworthy that the content of Fe element in FeN@C-7 catalyst is not more than 6 wt% (the metal dosage is lower than that of pure Nano Fe catalyst, but the catalytic effect is better [41]), which shows the highly efficient catalytic efficiency of monoatomic Fe catalyst. In addition, the mechanochemical ball milling method employed here facilitates scalable production, demonstrating excellent application prospects for propellant systems. 3.3 DFT calculations Ammonium salt molecules initially adsorb onto Fe single-atoms in the catalyst, leading to electron transfer phenomena. This adsorption process often involves the absorption or release of energy. The study of the electron transfer mechanism of molecules on the catalyst surface provides critical insights into the catalytic process. Notably, the electronic properties of the catalyst are critical for both the adsorption of molecules and the initiation and progression of reactions. For redox reactions, the positioning and electronic structure of the Fermi energy levels, along with the density of electronic states near these levels, directly influence the catalytic activity of the catalyst. To understand the catalytic mechanism of Fe single-atoms in FeN@C-7 for energetic ammonium salts, calculations were carried out using DFT theory. We chose one of the most stable models of graphite-loaded Fe atom catalysts to study [46]. The catalyst model is denoted as FeN4@C, which has the structure of FeN4 embedded in a graphite lattice (Fig. S13-a). The initial molecular model of FeN4@C was constructed using MS software, followed by structural optimization with the PBE functional. All computational parameters satisfied the predefined convergence criteria. Therefore, the adsorption models of the main pyrolysis products of AP, AN and ADN on the FeN4@C surface and their corresponding differential electron densities (the difference between the model and the corresponding atomic charge densities) were investigated. The Fe single-atoms in the catalyst plays a crucial role in the adsorption of these product molecules. Electrons in the outer d-orbitals of the Fe atom facilitate electron transfer between the catalyst surface and the adsorbed molecules, thereby contributing to the pyrolysis reaction of these molecules. Fig. 10 sequentially illustrates the adsorption models of NH3, HClO4, HNO3, and HN(NO2)2 molecules on the FeN4@C surface, along with the corresponding differential electron densities (yellow areas indicate increased electron densities, while blue areas signify decreased electron densities). Detailed adsorption modeling is provided in Figs. S13–S16. The adsorbed molecules significantly influence the differential electron density of the model, leading to a shift in the center of positive and negative electronegativity within the model. This shift can also be observed through changes in the electron cloud's shape. The strength of atomic interactions in bonded systems can be assessed by the energy value of the electron differential density. Upon comparing the energy values of the adsorbed NH3, HClO4, HNO3, and HN(NO2)2 molecules on the catalyst surface, it was determined that NH3 molecules are more likely to be adsorbed onto the FeN4@C catalyst surface. To further verify the adsorption of Fe atoms on these molecules, crystal orbital hamilton populations (COHP) were calculated for the adsorption models (Fig. S17). Comparison of the COHP of NH3 (0.08091 Ha), HClO4 (0.02939 Ha), HNO3 (0.00881 Ha), and HN(NO2)2 (0.01458 Ha) reveals that the bonding strength of the adsorption model of NH3 with the catalyst is the strongest. The pyrolysis of ammonium salt molecules was divided into several elementary reactions for DFT studies. The pyrolysis of NH3 was investigated as a common part of the energetic ammonium salts, and the ones of HClO4, HNO3 and HN(NO2)2 were investigated as characteristic parts of AP, AN and ADN in that order (R1–R3). The calculation of the lowest energy paths for the pyrolysis reactions and the partial densities of states (PDOS) can help to determine the difficulty of the chemical reactions. In these free energy diagrams, the free energy value of the structure is the sum of the free energies of its associated reactions as a whole. Fig. 11 -a shows the free energy step diagram for the thermal decomposition reaction (R6–R11) of NH3 on the surface of FeN4@C. The adsorption of NH3 on the FeN4@C surface releases 1.73 eV of energy, indicating that NH3 easily adsorbs onto Fe single-atoms. Furthermore, the pyrolysis of NH3 molecules on the catalyst surface primarily involves electron-loss oxidation reactions and necessitates heat absorption. The conversion of *NH2 to *NH is the rate-determining step (+1.70 eV). From the PDOS plots before and after adsorption, it can be seen that d-orbital electron density shifts towards the Fermi level, which is beneficial for electron transfer (Fig. 11-b). The free energies of the catalytic pyrolysis reactions of the acidic component of AP (HClO4) are shown in Fig. 12 -a. During the pyrolysis process, HClO4 sequentially releases energy, the reaction involves a reduction process, during which electrons are gained (R12–R20). Notably, the reaction of *HClO4 pyrolysis to produce *ClO3 and H2O releases the most energy (−3.63 eV). In comparison to the pyrolysis of the basic component (NH3), the pyrolysis of the acidic component involves more steps and results in greater heat release. Comparing the PDOS (Fig. 12-b), it can be observed that the d-orbital electron density around the model Fermi energy level is elevated, which is favorable for the catalytic pyrolysis of AP molecules. The d-orbital electrons are derived from the Fe atoms in the catalyst, and thus they play a key role in the catalytic pyrolysis of AP. Fig. 13 illustrates the free energy profile for the thermal decomposition reaction (R21–R28) of HNO3 on the FeN4@C surface. The pyrolysis of AN relies on the last step reaction to release energy, and the reactions of the intermediate products (*NO2 to *N) are relatively less exothermic. In contrast to AP, the molecular pyrolysis of AN exhibits a notable difference in energy release, largely due to variations in their acidic components. From the pyrolysis gas mass spectra of AN, it is evident that N2 (m/z = 28) and N2O (m/z = 44) are the final products, with their yields being quite similar (Fig. 6-e). As shown in Fig. 13-a, HNO3 (the acidic component of AN) has two primary pathways for complete pyrolysis: N2 and N2O, and the path that produces N2O is the lesser energy release. In contrast, HClO4 (the acidic component of AP) exhibits only one pyrolysis pathway (Fig. 12-a). A comparison of the free energy summary plots for the pyrolysis reactions of AP and AN (Fig. S18) reveals that AP undergoes pyrolysis with higher energy release compared to AN. This explains the underlying reason why AP combustion produces larger flames and shorter burning times compared to AN combustion (Fig. 9). The thermal decomposition of AN will only appear exothermic when the catalyst can maximize the conversion of *N to N2 (−5.46 eV + 0.96 eV = −4.50 eV) and N2O (−4.09 eV + 0.80 eV = −3.29 eV) rather than NO (−1.06 eV −0.12 eV + 1.75 eV = +0.57 eV). Since ADN pyrolysis generates HNO3 (R34), there are some parts that identical to the AN pyrolysis mechanism, about which the pyrolysis mechanism will not be repeated here. The catalytic pyrolysis of ADN is complicated, which has multiple reaction paths on the catalyst surface at the same time, and we investigated several major pyrolysis paths of ADN (R29–R38). Similar to AP and AN, the adsorption of ADN on the FeN4@C surface affects the movement of the d-orbital electrons towards the vicinity of the Fermi energy level, which favors the thermal decomposition reaction, as shown in Fig. 14 . Moreover, the first step reaction of HN(NO2)2 on a Fe single-atom occurs by combining with an H atom (produced by NH3) to produce H2O, which is analogous to the catalytic pyrolysis of HClO4 and HNO3. After that, some intermediates will continue to combine with H atoms to yield H2O and smaller intermediates. And others will directly break the bond to yield certain gaseous products (e.g., NO, O2, NO2 and HNO3), which do not require the participation of H atoms in these reactions. The higher molecular weight of these gaseous products, such as NO2 and HNO3, makes them less likely to escape and they will continue to participate in the pyrolysis reaction on the catalyst surface. In contrast, gas products with lower molecular weight, like NO, can easily desorb from the catalyst surface and be released into the environment. It was verified from the pyrolysis gas mass spectra that the yield of NO2 (m/z = 46) and HNO3 (m/z = 63) were almost undetectable. Among these intermediates, especially acidic molecules (such as HNO3) could further catalyze the pyrolysis of AND [6]. The production of O2 through pyrolysis is a distinctive feature of energetic ammonium salts. Given that the molecular oxygen equilibria for AP (+34.05 %), AN (+19.99 %), and ADN (+25.79 %) are all positive, these substances can supply oxygen to the system during combustion. To understand the mechanism of oxygen production by pyrolysis of such molecules, the free energies of some major oxygen-producing reactions during the pyrolysis of AP, AN and ADN were calculated (Fig. 15 ). The adsorption models and PDOS of the relevant molecules are shown in Figs. S19 and S20, and the chemical equations for the oxygen-producing reactions are shown in RS1–S14 (SI). For AP, all of its oxygen-producing reactions release energy, with the most energy released in the thermal decomposition of *ClO4 to form *ClO2 and O2 (−3.70 eV), much higher than that released in the relevant reactions of AN and ADN (Fig. 15-a). From Fig. 15-b, c, the reactions of O2 production by pyrolysis of *NO3 and *N(NO2) are exothermic and are the major reaction pathways for O2 generation from ADN. In addition, the pyrolysis of *NO3 may be the only pathway for O2 generation from AN. The pyrolysis of *NO2 and *NO to produce O2 requires absorption of energy (+5.06 eV and +6.75 eV, respectively), which is difficult. Whereas *HNO3 is the main reactant of AN (Fig. 13-a), the molecule readily reacts with H atoms to form *NO2 and H2O, which is exothermic (−2.97 eV). Therefore *HNO3 will thermally decompose towards the easier reaction path. Comparing the pyrolysis gas mass spectrometry data (Fig. 6), AP is more likely to produce O2 than AN and ADN, which confirms the accuracy of the simulation results. 4 Conclusions In summary, this study synthesized a series of graphite lattice-confined Fe single-atom catalysts using wet ball milling and investigated them to the catalytic pyrolysis of energetic ammonium salts. Thermal decomposition analyses and combustion flame analyses demonstrated that FeN@C-7 is highly effective in catalyzing the pyrolysis of these ammonium salts, leading to enhanced energy release. The thermal decomposition gases were analyzed, and the pyrolysis mechanisms of AP, AN and ADN on the Fe single-atom catalyst were proposed. DFT calculations were employed to study the pyrolysis of these ammonium salts. The free energy comparison indicates that the exothermic effect of AP is superior to that of AN. This is attributed to the longer reaction path and greater energy release during the pyrolysis of perchloric acid. For AN, the initial steps of the thermal decomposition release little energy (*HNO3 to *N for −2.40 eV), which is insufficient to meet the energy required for the ammonia thermal decomposition (*NH3 to *N for +3.02 eV). Thus, the pyrolysis of AN exhibits a heat-absorbing decomposition, which is consistent with the DSC analysis. Theoretical calculations indicate that the pyrolysis of AN behaves exothermic when the catalyst promotes the conversion of as much *N as possible into N2 (−4.50 eV) and N2O (−3.29 eV), rather than NO (+0.57 eV). The ADN has five main pyrolysis pathways and HNO3 is generated during the pyrolysis process, so some of the intermediate products are the same as those of AN. Due to the large number of intermediates and the presence of self-catalytic, ADN can be decomposed completely at around 200 °C. Furthermore, the oxygen-producing responses of AP, AN and ADN were investigated. It was learned that the oxygen production capacity of AP was the strongest, in agreement with the results of gas mass spectrometry. These findings are instructive for the further development of energetic ammonium salt pyrolysis catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The energetic ammonium salts represent a class of oxidizer materials that are extensively utilized in contemporary propellant systems. However, the catalytic pyrolysis mechanisms of these salts remain inadequately explored, hindering the efficient application of new energetic ammonium salts. In this study, taking typical energetic ammonium salts (ammonium perchlorate (AP), ammonium nitrate (AN) and ammonium dinitramide (ADN)) as examples, their pyrolysis on the surface of the prepared Fe single-atom catalysts and the combustion flames of the powders were investigated. We learned that Fe single-atoms can promote the pyrolysis and enhance the flame intensity of ammonium salts. The mechanism of Fe single-atom catalyzed ammonium salts has been investigated through density-functional-theory (DFT) calculations, and the results well explained the experimental phenomena. The AP molecule produces oxygen most readily, primarily through the pyrolysis of *ClO4 (−3.70 eV). The idea of solving the heat-absorbing decomposition of AN is proposed to catalyze its complete decomposition and to avoid the production of NO. The low decomposition temperature of ADN is due to the five major pyrolysis pathways of the molecule and the presence of self-catalytic intermediates. This paper offers guidelines for comprehending the pyrolysis and combustion mechanisms of energetic ammonium salts.
